titleStmt.title: Description of British Library, Harley Ch 43 A 66 A: Latin charter

availability.licence: These images and the content of British Library Harley Ch 43 A 66 A: Latin charter are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. See the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark page for usage details, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/.

notesStmt.note: Manuscript description based on Anglo-Jewish Historical Exhibition Royal Albert Hall. 1887. Catalogue and Olszowy-Schlanger, Judith. Hebrew and Hebrew-Latin Documents from Medieval England: a diplomatic and Palaeographical Study. Turnhout: Brill, 2015.

msContents.summary: Latin charter (Attached to the Latin grant is two Latin quitclaims, each with a Hebrew docket: Harley ch 43 A 66 B and Harley ch 43 A 66 C)

layoutDesc.layout: Columns: 1; ruled lines: 15; written lines: 15; Two other parchment leaves (Harley ch 43 A 66 B and Harley ch 43 A 66 C) are inserted into the fold on the bottom of the charter, held together by two seals.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Latin Gothic script of the 13th century.

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
